qas.question: When did Charles Taze Russell form a group?
Where did Russell and others form their group?
What was the purpose of Russell's group?
When Russell met Nelson H. Barbour in 1876, they jointly produced what book?
1914 would mark the end of a 2520 year period known as what?
What was the name of a member in Charles Taze Russell's group in 1870?

plausible_answers.text: the full establishment of God's kingdom on earth

qas.question: In what year did Nelson H. Barbour die?

plausible_answers.text: the fleshly return of Jesus Christ

qas.question: What was one of the doctrinal differences that Russell and Barbour had?

context: In <a0_0>1870<a0_0/>, Charles Taze Russell and others formed a group in <a1_0>Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania<a1_0/>, <a2_0>to study the Bible<a2_0/>. During the course of his ministry, Russell disputed many beliefs of mainstream Christianity including immortality of the soul, hellfire, predestination, <b8_0>the fleshly return of Jesus Christ<b8_0/>, the Trinity, and the burning up of the world. In 1876, Russell met <b5_0>Nelson H. Barbour<b5_0/>; later that year they jointly produced the book <a3_0>Three Worlds<a3_0/>, which combined restitutionist views with end time prophecy. The book taught that God's dealings with humanity were divided dispensationally, each ending with a "harvest," that Christ had returned as an invisible spirit being in 1874 inaugurating the "harvest of the Gospel age," and that 1914 would mark the end of a 2520-year period called "<a4_0>the Gentile Times<a4_0/>," at which time world society would be replaced by <b6_0>the full establishment of God's kingdom on earth<b6_0/>. Beginning in 1878 Russell and Barbour jointly edited a religious journal, Herald of the Morning. In June <b7_0>1879<b7_0/> the two split over doctrinal differences, and in July, Russell began publishing the magazine Zion's Watch Tower and Herald of Christ's Presence, stating that its purpose was to demonstrate that the world was in "the last days," and that a new age of earthly and human restitution under the reign of Christ was imminent.
